segments.text: Okay, this is an interview with Jim Ball of Vista Chemicals by Kelly Gamblin.
Do you agree to let A&M Archives have the results of this interview?
Yes, I do.
Thank you.
My first question is, what was your date of birth and where were you born?
February 27th, 1943, and I was born in Bramer, Missouri.
And what is your present age?
How did you decide to go into the armed services?

Well, it was a matter of the fact that I came from the Midwest, and it was always part of the ethic when I was growing up, is that young men would go into service, particularly if their country was at war.
At the time that I was starting to deal with this, it was early in the Vietnam conflict in 1965, let's say.
And by the time I graduated in 1966, both the sort of support from myself within and from my friends was that we should go in, most of us.
And in addition to that, I was going to get drafted in any case.
So you had those things happen at the same time.
So I ultimately did go in the Army then, but volunteered just shortly before the draft.
OK.
Which branch of the armed services did you join?
In the Army.
OK. What was your rank?
Well, I went in as an enlisted man, and then went through the officer candidate school program.
And I was a first lieutenant when I got out of the service.
Okay, now as a first lieutenant, what was your job specifically in the field?
In Vietnam was, first of all, I was an infantry platoon leader with the First Air Cavalry Division.
And then I did that for the first six months, roughly.
And then for the last six months, I was an air operations officer for my battalion.
Okay.
So you entered Vietnam shortly after high school graduation?
After college.
Oh, after college.
Okay, so how old were you exactly?
I've been, let's see, would have been 24, I guess, when I went to Vietnam.
Okay, I see.
So you thought it was your duty to go over there and help?
Well, in the early days, before I joined the service, I thought it was my duty.
And then-
After I got involved in the Army and got caught up in the program and the training and so forth, I was very successful in the Army.
And I was in the state side for nearly two years.
And I ended up being in the infantry school.
And I was a tactical officer in the infantry school.
So I was very much involved in teaching other people
and training and how to fight and so forth.

And so by the time I went to Vietnam, I not only felt it was my duty, which I did, Vietnam was becoming more controversial by then, 1968, but still we didn't have the amount of controversy in 1968 as we had starting after the Tet Offensive, really, in 68.
We didn't have as much controversy, so I did go, I guess, a combination of feeling it was a duty
And also, I was trained to go.
It was something I was doing.

Well, when you actually found out, I mean, you got your notice that you were going to be shipped off to Vietnam, I mean, were you, was it a combination of excitement or fear or exactly how did you feel emotionally about going?
Well, first of all, I volunteered to go to Vietnam.
I volunteered two different times, as a matter of fact, and could not get released from my current assignment to go.
until I had completed that.
And so then I went as a matter of due course because it was just expected after the one-year assignment in Fort Benning I was on in infantry school.
So it was more a matter of just kind of filling out something that was a plan for a long period of time.
But certainly, sure, excitement, some fear, obviously, and so on.
OK.
I've been told that Vietnam is a beautiful country.
I was just wondering, when you finally arrived there, what was your initial impression of, say, the country, the people, their kind of culture?
What did you feel about them?
Well, Vietnam looks like a lot of Southeast Asia.
And there are parts of it that are scenic.
I think they would be primarily along the coastline and in the mountains.
I saw almost none of the coastline.
Of course, when I first arrived, if that's what you're asking, I landed on K, I guess it was.
And from there,
We went out to the field right away, and the particular area we were in was not very attractive.
And then we worked in the coastal plains for a while, and that area was not particularly attractive either.
But then after about a month or so, we went into the mountains in a jungle mountain setting while it was attractive, if you will.
When you arrived in Vietnam, what did you feel was your specific purpose there?
as a person, and what were you doing for your country?
Well, I was there as an infantry officer, so my job was to organize and lead my men to close with and destroy the enemy.
So by then, they were already operating on search and destroy missions by this time?
Search and destroy is only a narrow definition of a broad kind of tactics.
And certainly those tactics were well established long before that.

The only reason that once you get past the phase, for instance, in something like Vietnam where the role of the military is to train others, then the mission in a war is to do exactly that in one way or another, search and destroy.
Okay.
Did you think you could win the war?
Yes, yeah.
Okay.
When you first went over there, was it?
the kind of idea that you could win it quickly without any problems?
No, no, by no means.
I landed in May of 68, and by that time we'd been in Vietnam already for three years.
By virtue of being in the infantry school in Fort Benning and with lots of returning soldiers from Vietnam,
lots of firsthand stories as to what the problems were in fighting the war.
Our training was, we were constantly trying to update our training to be current with the situation and be realistic in the situation.
So there was never, it should never have been any expectation on the part of people who were trained that there was going to be a fast or easy type of conversation.
Did you ever get to the point where you almost thought, this is impossible, this is never going to work?
Oh, yes, sure.
You have ups and downs in those kinds of things.
Right.
I mean, part of those doubts could only come about as you experienced different kinds of events that happened during the period.
For instance, in the first part of my tour, we operated in the I Corps.
That's the northern part of South Vietnam.
And we're working along in the mountains along close to the Asha Valley.
And that area.
Had been a very hot area in the early part of 1968.
And by the early fall of 1968 was actually starting to calm down.
We were running into much less resistance.
And we.
Picked up.
And on very short order, in less than 24 hours, we moved the whole division south to work along the Cambodian border.
And we were going into an area which basically no large-scale friendly allied or just friendly forces had operated since the beginning of the Vietnam conflict.
It had been no man's land for all that period of time.
And we were staging on a little
remote airstrip to go into a combat assault by helicopter into an area that was just a few thousand meters from the Cambodian border.
And what virtually happened is that we were there, and helicopters were coming in to pick us up.
And one of my men had a transistor radio on, and Lyndon Johnson announced that we were going to cease the bombing in North Vietnam.
So at times like that, some despair would set in and say, you know, this is never going to work if we're not going to be willing to take this and fight it to its fullest extent.
One of the things that we've discussed in this class to a pretty big extent was how were you going to win the hearts and minds of the Vietnamese people?
What exactly did that mean to you?
Well, first of all, I have virtually no personal experience with it.
because I was only exposed to the Vietnamese civilian population a very few times.
But the slogan meant, I think in general, is that we will go in and try to show the Vietnamese people that they can protect themselves, first of all,
and that we would be willing to help them, not only protect themselves, but to grow as a country, grow economically, and grow politically.
And our missions there then were to bolster the Army, to provide medical care, to provide, in fact, some agricultural training was done in some areas.
to win the support of the people and to win, you know, literally their hearts.
That means the support part of it.
And the minds is that they were, on an intellectual basis, we would identify with the Americans as friendly and with democracy as a way of government that they should be pursuing.
We talked also about how Arvin was hard to work with, partly because they were not as
at least according to a professor, they were not nearly as skilled as the American troops, even though they had American training.
Did you have problems, or did you even work with them to start with?
I never, so I can't really comment.
I have some doubts about those reports, though, that they were not as skilled as American soldiers.
I think the problem was
was more likely to be is that large parts of the Vietnamese army was corrupt and the soldiers perceived this to be true, and so therefore they weren't motivated to fight.
It wasn't a matter of skill per se.
MS. Do you happen to know?
I don't know no more about that than people who read about it.
I mean, that's all I know.
You don't know anything about their desertion rates?
I don't, no.
That's basically hearsay on your part?
Yeah, more than the things that you read from others.
We talked about also about how during the later part of the war years when it was getting to be very controversial that some of the troops even decided that they weren't going to fight.
U.S. troops.
That they just had enough.
Did you ever encounter any problems in this?
I think that phenomenon really...
started to happen in the early 70s.
That's when we started to hear about those reports in some major way.
And we heard about the fraggings, for instance.
In any war, in any combat situation, you're going to have a few people who, for one reason or another, will refuse to fight.
I personally, within my platoon,
only had one person, I would say, that that would really apply to for sure.
I mean, some others who were very ineffective in fighting, but that was more from just an absolute fear than anything else.
So it wasn't a problem.
And also, one of the things that I believe is true is when you hear or read about Vietnam
one has to distinguish carefully between what time period it was and also what sort of unit that one was talking about.

Another aspect of the same thing, and I'll make the same observation as on drugs, is in the later part of the Vietnam conflict, we heard an awful lot about the use of drugs by soldiers, and that was obviously true from things that have happened since then, reports we've heard since then.
But I think both in the case of
of the use of drugs and in things like morale problems, it was a function often of the units that people were in as well.
And the 1st Air Cav was a reasonably well-run unit, and it was still considered to be an elite type of operation.
It was an air operations.
It and the 101st Airborne were the only two in Vietnam.
A large number of the officers were volunteer, volunteered wanting to do that specific thing.
And so we didn't have the problems, I don't think.
Well, I should make one of the observations.
That is, we were in the field all the time.
If you're in the field and you didn't have access to the civilian population, you didn't have access to drugs.
Now, my impression is that the combination of drugs being late in the war kind of led and
and being part of a so-so unit that didn't have very good morale led to a lot of those combat desertions that you're talking about.
What were your feelings about the students who were protesting back in the States, the anti-war movement?
Well, I'm sure that a large number of those students were motivated because they really believed what we were doing was unjust.

But the truth of the matter is most of them were really only motivated to go out and do very much about demonstrating because they were also fearful for their own personal safety of being involved in something that they weren't involved in.
So, I mean, in many cases, I can remember having thoughts is that I believe that some of these people believe in what they're doing.
But frequently, why I believe that they really didn't want to go themselves was the main issue they were working on.
Right.
I think you're right.
Okay.
Looking back now, do you think Vietnam could be won?
Could it have been won?
Well, it certainly, yes, it could have been won, but only by an effort that involved probably ultimately an invasion of North Vietnam, but at least a more extensive bombing.

of north vietnam yeah okay do you think it was ever well let me put it this way do you think it would have been helpful for the u.s to go into north vietnam i mean literally with troops and all well if would have been helpful in the narrow sense of winning the war yes but in what was good for the united states no because the the the loss of life would have been enormous unless you

basically decimated the North Vietnamese people by bombing ahead of time and that would have been a tragedy as well because I think the larger lesson in Vietnam is that it ultimately probably didn't mean as much as we thought it did in 1965.
And so anything that we might have done to have made it a larger scale operation probably wouldn't have been worth it.
I mean after all in Vietnam our
Our enemies were, first of all, the North Vietnamese, and they were being supported by the Chinese and by the Russians.
Well, the North Vietnamese don't really matter today as far as being someone who is not a friend and supporter of the United States.
And the Chinese, the relationships are much better.
Tiananmen Square of last year notwithstanding, those will again improve, I believe.
and obviously things are improving with the Russians.
So as time has shown, it's just that Vietnam wasn't worth it at the cost it did have, and so it certainly wouldn't have been worth it to do anymore.
Well, if there had been an invasion of North Vietnam of ground troops, was there a real threat of the Chinese or Moscow intervening into the war, do you think?
I don't think the Russians would have.
And on the Chinese, it's difficult to say.
The precedent had been set, of course, in Korea for them to have done so.
And the Chinese in those days, I think, were much more prone to do so, but they were also tied up in their own cultural revolution at the time, too.
I don't know.
I mean, I don't think there is any clear coming, but it would have been a big risk.
It would have been a risk for sure because most of the support, the direct support the North Vietnamese were getting in those days in terms of materiel and advisors, I think, were coming from China.
Okay.
So when did you leave Vietnam to come back to the States?
In May of 69.
Okay.
And did you have any problems fitting back into civilian life?
No.
OK, so how did you get involved with Vista Chemicals?
Well, let's see.
I came back and decided I wasn't quite ready yet to go to work.
And so I went to graduate school for a semester.
But my plan all the time was that I would use that period of time while I was in graduate school to start interviewing, looking for jobs.
And I did so, interviewed with a number of companies,
And I had a good friend working for Conoco, which is the predecessor to Vista.
And the combination of knowing some people there and having a very favorable interview and liking what they had to say is as simple a matter as that.
So I joined Conoco then in September of 69.
OK. And what was your starting position?
Did you have a title?
I like a title.
Everyone has like a title.
I was on the oil side of Conoco, and that was a marketing training.
Okay.
So how long have you been with Conoco and Vista?
20 years.
Oh, a long time.
69 double.
And so now you're senior vice president.
And so how did you get to that position, besides lots of hard work?
Well, I mean, that's probably it, isn't it?
Sure.
I mean, lots of hard work and lots of opportunity presented.
to me and lots of support from a lot of other people.
Well, do you think that it's important for, say, my generation and the ones that follow to know about Vietnam and what happened there and why?
Sure, absolutely.
Why do you think it's important for them to know?
Well, I think it's only important in the same context as that all major events
in our history are important for all people, including people of your generation, to know about.
Certainly the events of the 60s and the early 70s set into place, set into motion, a lot of things in this country and our feeling about warfare
is only one of those, but that's it.
That's it.
And we are dealing with societal problems today that are still emanating from people.
So understanding what Vietnam was about would be as important in trying to understand those.
We have, you know, a number of people who are veterans of Vietnam who are claiming
all kinds of psychological and physiological problems related to the service in Vietnam.
And if you're going to have those people out claiming that, well, then you ought to have some recognition of what was that all about.
I think there's probably been a lot of increased awareness because of the movies that have been out lately, like Fourth of July.
That appeals to a lot of the younger generation.
Yeah, those people.
Those people, I mean, the people that were, I mean, the very obvious cases were people who made enormous sacrifices.
And for them to have made that sacrifice and to be part of our society, society needs to understand what their role was and what they did.
And it must be difficult, extremely difficult for those people.
to know in their heart is that what they did at the time, they may or may not have thought was the right thing.
To know that after some period of time, society no longer supported it.
And now, you know, I am suggesting is that history has proven it probably didn't matter a whole great deal, as it turns out.
It only happened, it was only important because that's what it was important
to support the activities of the country at that time, and we must have a citizenry which is willing to do that.
Well, have you ever gone back to Vietnam?
No, I haven't.
Do you think you ever would?
Oh, yes.
I have a file right over here I can show you.
As soon as I can go back with State Department sanction, I'll go.
Wow.
My prof, I asked him the same question, and he said he visits Vietnam.
Does he?
and some of the other Southeast Asian countries, like Cambodia and Laos.
And I asked him how the people responded to him, and he said that they were just great.
Well, I'd like to talk to him about how he does it.
I mean, quite seriously, I'd like to get his name and his telephone number, if I might, and talk to him about that.
Because the extent to which I've investigated it, the problem is on getting a visa.
First of all, you cannot get a visa in this country.
So what one has to do is to go to some place like Bangkok and then apply for a visa.
And it's a very uncertain process.
It takes a lot of time.
And I don't really have the time to go to Bangkok and then wait around for a week or two until I get a visa.
But I might like to talk to him and see.
Maybe he's got an entree that I don't understand.
I'm sure he can help.
Okay, I will.
I guess my final question is, have you ever been to Washington to see the...
Veterans War Memorial.
What was your impression when you saw that?
I'll tell you because part of it is somewhat humorous.
Most of it is not.
But yes, I did.
I went to see it.
I can't recall what year it was now.
It must have been dedicated in the early fall of about 1984 or 5.
Does that sound right?
Sometime around that.
Maybe a little later.
At any case, I was in Washington, D.C. for a meeting that takes place in October of every year, so I know when I was in Washington anyway, and went to see the memorial.
And it had only been open at that time for a few weeks, and it was kind of a rainy, cold day.
And I went down, and the ground around the memorial, they put sod down, but it wasn't very well put down.
It was very muddied around there in the end.
virtually had to walk on what looked like packing crates, or these skids you put underneath for forklifts to pick up.
And he kind of walked across that to get to it.
And I thought that was very appropriate for Vietnam.
It kind of had this construction site look in the mud.
So that was one thing.
But once I got to the wall, then it became a very emotional experience.
Not extremely emotional, but a bit emotional.
And I have been back.
probably since I do go to Washington quite a bit, I've been back to it probably three or four more times since then, once with my family.
And it's always with some emotion.
And I particularly like also the statue that's at the end of it.
I think it's very lifelike.
Have you seen it?
No, but I've been told about it.
Yeah, I think you really should see it.
I would love to.
It's very lifelike, and it's very...
representative, in fact, of the type of gear that soldiers wore in Vietnam.
I mean, you know, down to the way they tied their boots and the way their pants are bloused out over the boots and a towel around one guy's neck and so forth.
And you walk around behind the equipment, it's very authentic looking.
So I thought it was very well done.
And the facial expressions and so forth are very good.
That's very interesting.
Well, are there any closing comments you'd like to make?
No, not at all.
Well, I thank you very much for this interview.
I'm sure it would be very enlightening for someone else as it has been for me.
Thank you.
